Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Improving Design for Additive Manufacturing through Physically-integrated Design Concepts Generated from Computationally Efficient Graph Coloring Techniques

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration: Additive manufacturing or 3D printing has been hailed as the third industrial revolution because of the unique way it changes how products are conceived, designed, manufactured and distributed to end users. This research project addresses key scientific and engineering barriers that currently prevent the production of additively manufactured products at an industrially-relevant scale. In particular, the project focuses on how to better design products that will be produced via additive manufacturing by considering manufacturing constraints and challenges associated with assembling parts into final products. The study will result in fast algorithms for generating and selecting design concepts that have the minimum number of parts required to cover all functional requirements and that meet constraints imposed by the additive manufacturing process. This will facilitate high-volume, mass production of 3D printed products, thereby furthering the practicality and economic impact of additive manufacturing. The project spans several disciplines through a joint effort between the University at Buffalo (UB) and Rochester Institute of Technology (RIT). The project will enhance the curriculum related to design for additive manufacturing at the two participating universities by introducing results from this research into existing courses. Outreach activities will promote the recruitment of women and minorities to advanced manufacturing through workshops aimed at K-12 students organized in partnership with the Tech-Savvy program at UB. The research community will be engaged through a road-mapping workshop on computationally efficient methods in decision-based design. <br/><br/>The objective of this research is to define a prescribed theoretical framework and practical methods for classifying and generating physically integrated design concepts that can be realized effectively through additive manufacturing. The framework is based on the independence of functional requirements principle and modeling of physical integration problems as graph coloring problems. The research will result in new, computationally efficient (polynomial-time) graph-coloring algorithms based on discharging techniques in combination with Combinatorial Nullstellensatz. The new algorithms and design framework will be demonstrated and evaluated on representative design problems with the resulting designs being realized through additive manufacturing. Manufacturing productivity measures such as surface roughness, buildup time and cost, will be considered.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this project was to establish a theoretical framework for evaluating and generating physically integrated design concepts suitable for additive manufacturing applications. The project aims to employ the physical integration concept and helps designers generate design alternatives that have less complexity while allowing the independence of Functional Requirements to ensure reducing the chance of product failure. To implement this concept, a multidisciplinary team of researchers with expertise in graph theory, manufacturing, and engineering design has been formed. The team has developed graph coloring algorithms to model the changes in the functional requirements of a product and determine the minimum number of physical parts needed to meet product functionalities. Besides graph coloring algorithms, the team has developed optimization and simulation models to show the effect of part separation in enhancing the productivity of additive manufacturing processes where sub-parts with different geometry and shapes can be packed into the limited workspace of 3D printers and simultaneous printing of several parts on multiple 3D printers would be possible. Due to the multidisciplinary nature of the project, this research also has impacts on other disciplines, beyond additive manufacturing such as the repair and maintenance industry. 

The project outcomes inform the additive manufacturing industry by bringing new considerations (e.g., design for assembly, design for physical integration) into design decisions. The project findings showed how simplifying product structures and the way products are assembled, could potentially add valuable insights into both successes and failures of products manufactured by additive manufacturing. A wide range of methods has been created. To name a few, optimization techniques have been developed to find the optimal number of parts and their corresponding orientations for assembly-based design in additive manufacturing; part decomposition algorithms have been developed to separate a part into several pieces and to place the decomposed parts onto multiple batches; simulation models have been established to analyze the impact of the number of parts and their printing orientations on the production time in additive manufacturing; and data analytics efforts have been conducted to show the extent and scope of product failure and the needs for simplifying product structure and considering the independence of functional requirements.  

Education and outreach efforts include timely training and mentoring of graduate and undergraduate students; curriculum development;  incorporating the research outcomes into the design and manufacturing-related courses; journal publications; and presentations at a variety of conferences such as the ASME International Design Engineering Technical Conferences & Computers and Information in Engineering Conference and ASME Manufacturing Science & Engineering Conference.
